Introduction

Pityriasis rosea is a benign, self-limited condition characterized by a distinctive rash with erythematous, oval lesions on the trunk and proximal extremities.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The pathophysiology of pityriasis rosea remains unknown; however, a viral etiology has been hypothesized because the rash is preceded by a viral prodrome of headache, malaise, and pharyngitis in some patients.



Risk factors that may predispose individuals to develop pityriasis rosea include:



  • Age: primarily affects adolescents and young adults; peak incidence is between age 10 and 35

  • Recent viral illness

  • Seasonality: more common during the spring and fall

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of pityriasis rosea begins with a solitary, annular, erythematous, scaly lesion, known as a herald patch, on the neck or trunk.  As the herald patch increases in size and fades centrally, multiple clusters of small, erythematous, oval lesions appear on the trunk and proximal extremities.  These lesions follow tension lines in a Christmas-tree pattern (

figure 1
) on the trunk.  The rash may be pruritic or asymptomatic and typically spares the face, palms, and soles.  Some patients report a viral prodrome of headache, malaise, and pharyngitis.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of pityriasis rosea is made clinically; the characteristic rash with a history of a herald patch confirms the diagnosis.  However, laboratory evaluation may be indicated to exclude other diagnoses with a similar rash morphology in some patients.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of pityriasis rosea includes:



  • Secondary syphilis:  Although pityriasis rosea is similar, the exanthem of secondary syphilis is typically maculopapular and involves the palms and soles.  A rapid plasma reagin or VDRL test may be indicated in sexually active patients to exclude secondary syphilis.

  • Tinea corporis:  Tinea corporis presents with an annular plaque with central clearing and a peripheral scale, similar to a herald patch.  However, patients with tinea corporis do not develop a Christmas-tree rash.

  • Nummular eczema:  Nummular eczema causes a dry, erythematous plaque that is intensely pruritic and most commonly occurs on the extremities.

Management



Management of pityriasis rosea is primarily supportive and focused on symptomatic relief.  Topical corticosteroids or antihistamines may relieve pruritus, and emollients may soothe dry skin.  Patients should avoid hot showers and harsh soaps or detergents, which can aggravate the rash.  In addition, patients should be reassured that pityriasis rosea is a self-limited condition.

Prognosis



Pityriasis rosea is a self-limited condition that typically resolves within 6-8 weeks.  Recurrences are rare, with most patients experiencing complete resolution of symptoms.  However, some patients may develop postinflammatory hyperpigmentation that may persist for several weeks to months following resolution of the rash.

Summary
